Authors: Neil O. Polans, Paul D. Sorensen, Dayle E. Saar
Title:
A Phylogenetic Analysis of the genus Dahlia (Asteraceae)
Based on Internal and External Transcribed Spacer Regions of Nuclear
Ribosomal DNA.
Abstract:
The genus Dahlia presently consists of 35 species,
primarily from Mexico. Species are usually placed in four sections:
Pseudodendron, Epiphytum, Entemophyllon, and Dahlia, based largely on
morphological characters, supplemented with cytological, geographical,
and biochemical data. Combined molecular sequence data from both the
internal and external transcribed spacer regions (ITS and ETS), located
within the nuclear ribosomal gene repeat unit, are used to infer a
phylogeny of the genus. Section Entemophyllon forms a very well-defined
clade based on these data. Dahlia merckii and D. tubulata are positioned
between sect. Entemophyllon the remaining taxa. Sections Pseudodendron
and Epiphytum are closely allied with each other and a few species from
sect. Dahlia to form the variable root clade (VRC), which incorporates
all species with unusual underground structures, along with some species
exhibiting the more typical tuberous type. The remaining species of
sect. Dahlia form a well-defined clade, the core Dahlia clade
(CDC).
